bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Henry Rose Carter, March 14, 1922

div1.p: Truby believes that Lazear probably did tell Carroll he was bitten by a mosquito at Las Animas, but that Reed and others felt Lazear had purposely allowed himself to be bitten. He comments on Agramonte's role in the yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Henry Rose Carter, March 14, 1922

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT
AIR SERVICE
OFFICE OF THE CHIEF SURGEON
WASHINGTON
March 14/22

div1.p:
I have been too busy to answer
your interesting letter before
seeing to the many details
requiring all of my time pending
departure tomorrow.

I am sure Carrol was correct
in all of his statements and
the one that Lazear told him (Carrol)
that he had been bitten at Las Animas
is also probably correct. However
I have a distinct recollection
that Major Reed and all of the
other doctors at camp Columbia at
that time felt that Lazear had
been allowing his mosquitoes
to bite him freely and that
2
the chances were that he
contracted yellow fever from
one of those bites. I also have
a feeling that Lazear when
he was sick with yellow fever
made the statement he did
with a view to protecting
his family in case there should
be any trouble about his
insurance. I think it was
so interpreted by Major Reed-
Lazear was very sick from
the first and I think he had
little hope of getting over the
attack-

Agramonte's statements
do not accord with my
recollection of affairs and
are not in accord with
Carrol's statements- Agramonte
was never an active worker
3
on the Board and had practically
nothing to do with the work assigned
to the other members by Major Reed-
Carrol was wholly occupied with
the study of the intestinal flora-
Lazear was told to devote his
time to the mosquito theory.

Agramonte was to do post
mortems and any pathological work
that was required. He was not
stationed at Camp Columbia with
the other members of the Board,
and came to Camp Columbia
very infrequently- In my opinion
he deserves credit as a member
of the Board for the results
accomplished by the Board, but
I think he did little and
deserves little credit for
the actual work which resulted in
in the discovery of the.
proving Finlay's ideas that the
disease was carried by mosquitoes.

Please pardon this hasty
letter, I am just closing
my correspondence and
everything as we are nearly
ready to leave for San Francisco
div1.closer: Very Cordially yours E Truby Truby
